translation: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job; and that man was blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil.
And there were born to him seven sons and three daughters.

And his possessions were seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she-asses, and a very great household; and that man was the greatest of all the sons of the east.
And his sons would go and hold a feast in the house of each one on his day, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.

And when the days of feasting had gone their round, Job sent and consecrated them; and he rose early in the morning and offered burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did all the days.
Now it came to pass on the day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, that Satan also came among them.
And the LORD said to Satan, From where do you come? And Satan answered the LORD and said, From roaming about on the earth and from walking up and down in it.
And the LORD said to Satan, Have you set your heart upon My servant Job? For there is none like him in the earth, a man blameless and upright, who fears God and turns away from evil.
Then Satan answered the LORD and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?”
Have you not yourself set a hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have burst forth in the land.
But now stretch forth Your hand, I pray, and touch all that he has; surely he will curse You to Your face.
And the LORD said to Satan, Behold, all that he has is in your hand; only against himself do not stretch out your hand. So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD.
And it came to pass on the day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their firstborn brother.
And a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing, and the donkeys were grazing beside them.”
And Sheba fell upon them and took them away, and the young men they struck down with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped, I only, to tell you.
While this one was still speaking, another also came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned among the flock and the young men and consumed them, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”

While this one was still speaking, another came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three bands and fell upon the camels and took them away, and the young men they struck down with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
While this one was still speaking, another also came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their firstborn brother.”
And behold, a great wind came from beyond the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young men and they died; and I alone have escaped to tell you.
Then Job arose and tore his robe and shaved his head, and he fell to the ground and worshiped.
And he said, Naked I came forth from my mother’s womb, and naked I shall return there; the LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.
In all this Job did not sin, nor did he charge God with folly.
And it came to pass on the day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, that Satan also came among them to present himself before the LORD.
And the LORD said to Satan, From where do you come? And Satan answered the LORD and said, From roaming about on the earth and from walking up and down in it.

And the LORD said to Satan, Have you set your heart upon my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a man blameless and upright, who fears God and turns away from evil? And still he holds fast his integrity, though you incited me against him to swallow him up without cause.
Then Satan answered the LORD and said, “Skin for skin; indeed, all that a man has he will give for his life.”
But stretch out now Your hand, and touch his bone and his flesh; surely he will bless You to Your face.
And the LORD said to Satan, Behold, he is in your hand; only guard his life.
So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD and struck Job with loathsome sores from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
And he took for himself a potsherd to scrape himself with it, and he sat among the ashes.
Then his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast to your integrity? Bless God and die.”
And he said to her, You speak as one of the foolish women speaks. Shall we indeed receive the good from God, and shall we not receive the evil? In all this Job did not sin with his lips.

Now when Job’s three friends heard of all this evil that had come upon him, they came each from his own place: Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite; and they met together to come to mourn with him and to comfort him.
And they lifted up their eyes from afar and did not recognize him, and they lifted up their voice and wept; and each one tore his robe, and they cast dust upon their heads toward heaven.
And they sat down with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spoke a word to him, for they saw that the pain was very great.
After this Job opened his mouth and cursed his day.
And Job answered and said:
Let the day perish on which I was born, and the night which said, “A man is conceived.”
That day—let it be darkness; let not God seek it from above, nor let light shine upon it.
Let darkness and deep shadow redeem it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of day terrify it.
That night—may thick darkness seize it; let it not rejoice among the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.
Behold, that night—let it be barren; let no song of joy come into it.
Let those curse it who curse the day, who are ready to rouse up Leviathan.
Let the stars of its dawn be dark; let it hope for light, but there is none, and let it not behold the eyelids of the morning.
Because it did not shut the doors of my womb, nor hide trouble from my eyes.
Why did I not die from the womb? Why did I not expire as I came forth from the belly?
Why did knees receive me, and why breasts, that I should suck?
For now I would have lain down and been quiet; I would have slept; then I would be at rest.
With kings and counselors of the earth, who built desolate places for themselves.
Or with princes who had gold for themselves, who filled their houses with silver.
Or like a hidden miscarriage I would not be; like infants that never saw the light.
There the wicked cease from troubling, and there the weary of strength find rest.
Together the prisoners are at ease; they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
The small and the great are there, and the servant is free from his master.
Why is light given to the weary, and life to those bitter of soul?
Who long for death, and it comes not, and dig for it more than for hidden treasures.
Who rejoice to exultation, who are glad when they find the grave.
To a man whose way is hidden, and whom God has hedged in.
For my sighing comes before my bread, and my groanings pour out like water.
For the thing I greatly feared has come upon me, and what I dreaded has overtaken me.
I was not at ease, neither was I quiet, neither had I rest; and trouble came.
Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
If one ventures a word to you, will you be wearied? Yet who can withhold himself from speaking?
Behold, you have instructed many, and weak hands you have strengthened.
Your words have upheld him who stumbled, and you have strengthened feeble knees.
But now it has come to you, and you are weary; it touches you, and you are dismayed.
Is not your fear of God your confidence, and the integrity of your ways your hope?
Remember, I pray you, who ever perished being innocent? And where were the upright cut off?
As I have seen, those who plow iniquity and sow trouble reap the same.
By the breath of God they perish, and by the blast of His anger they are consumed.
The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions are broken.
The strong lion perishes for lack of prey, and the whelps of the lioness are scattered.
Now a word was stolen to me, and my ear received a whisper of it.
In disquieting thoughts from the visions of the night, when deep sleep falls upon men.
Fear came upon me, and trembling, which made the multitude of my bones to quake.
Then a spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood on end.
It stood still, but I could not discern its appearance; a form was before my eyes, there was silence, then I heard a voice.
Shall mortal man be more righteous than God? Or shall a man be pure before his Maker?
Behold, in his servants he puts no trust, and he charges his angels with error.
How much more those who dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed before the moth.
From morning to evening they are shattered; without anyone regarding it, they perish forever.
Is not their tent-cord torn away within them? They die, and not in wisdom.
Call now; is there anyone who will answer you? And to which of the holy ones will you turn?
For vexation slays the foolish man, and jealousy puts the simple one to death.
I myself have seen the fool taking root, and I suddenly cursed his dwelling.
His children are far from deliverance; they are crushed in the gate, and there is no one to rescue.
Whose harvest the hungry shall eat, and take it even out from among the thorns, and the thirsty shall swallow up their wealth.
For trouble does not come forth from the dust, nor does toil sprout up from the ground.
For man is born to trouble, and the sons of the flame soar on high.
But as for me, I would seek to God, and to God I would commit my cause.
Who does great things beyond searching out, wonders without number.
He gives rain upon the face of the earth, and sends waters upon the open fields.
To set the lowly on high, and those who mourn are lifted up to safety.
He frustrates the devices of the crafty, so that their hands perform no sound wisdom.
He takes the wise in their own craftiness, and the counsel of the crooked is brought to haste.
By day they meet with darkness, and at noonday they grope as in the night.
But he saves the poor from the sword of their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
So the poor has hope, and iniquity shuts its mouth.
Behold, blessed is the man whom God corrects; therefore do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
For he wounds, but he also binds up; he smites, and his hands make whole.
In six troubles he will deliver you, and in seven no evil shall touch you.
In famine He will redeem you from death, and in war from the power of the sword.
From the scourge of the tongue you shall be hidden, and you shall not fear devastation when it comes.
At destruction and at famine you shall laugh, and from the beasts of the earth you shall not be afraid.
For you shall be in covenant with the stones of the field, and the beast of the field shall be at peace with you.
And you shall know that your tent is at peace, and you shall visit your dwelling and shall miss nothing.
And you shall know that your seed is many, and your offspring as the grass of the earth.
You shall come to the grave in a ripe old age, like a shock of grain comes up in its season.
Behold this, we have searched it out; so it is. Hear it, and know it for yourself.
Then Job answered and said:
Oh that my vexation were indeed weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together!
For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas; therefore my words are swallowed up.
For the arrows of the Almighty are within me, whose poison my spirit drinks; the terrors of God array themselves against me.
Does the wild donkey bray over grass, or does the ox low over its fodder?
Can that which is tasteless be eaten without salt, or is there any flavor in the juice of the mallow?
My soul refuses to touch them; they are as loathsome as the bread I eat.
Oh that my request might come to pass, and that God would grant my hope.
That it would please God to crush me, that He would let loose His hand and cut me off.
And it would still be my comfort; I would exult in pain that does not spare, for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
What is my strength, that I should wait in hope? And what is my end, that I should prolong my soul?
Is my strength the strength of stones, or is my flesh bronze?
Is it not that my help is in me, and sound wisdom is driven far from me?
To him who is faint, kindness is due from his friend, even if he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
My brothers have dealt deceitfully like a wadi, like the channels of torrents that pass away.
Which are turbid from ice; upon them the snow hides itself.
In the time when they grow warm, they vanish; when it is hot, they are extinguished from their place.
The paths of their way wind and turn; they go up into the waste and perish.
The caravans of Tema looked; the travelers of Sheba waited for them.
They were ashamed because they had trusted; they came there and were confounded.
For now you have become nothing; you see a terror and are afraid.
Did I ever say, “Give to me,” or, “Offer a bribe for me from your wealth”?
Or, deliver me from the hand of the adversary, or redeem me from the hand of the ruthless.
Teach me, and I will be silent; and make me understand how I have erred.
How forceful are words of uprightness! But what does your reproof reprove?
Do you intend to reprove mere words, and the speeches of one in despair as wind?
Indeed, you cast lots even over the fatherless, and you bargain away your own friend.
Now therefore, be so kind as to turn to me; and before your faces, is it that I lie?
Return now, I pray you, let there be no injustice; yes, return again, my righteousness is in it.
Is there injustice on my tongue? Does not my palate discern calamities?
Is there not a warfare for man upon earth, and are not his days like the days of a hired laborer?
Like a servant who longs for the shade, and like a hired man who waits for his wages.
So I have been made to inherit months of vanity, and wearisome nights are appointed to me.
When I lie down, I say, “When shall I arise, and the night be measured out?” and I am full of tossings until the dawn.
My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust; my skin is broken and loathsome.
My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, and come to an end without hope.
Remember that my life is but a breath; my eye shall not again see good.
The eye of him who sees me shall behold me no more; your eyes will be upon me, but I shall not be.
The cloud is consumed and vanishes away; so he who goes down to Sheol shall not come up.
He shall return no more to his house, neither shall his place know him again.
I also will not restrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit, I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am I a sea, or a sea monster, that you set a guard over me?
For I said, “My bed shall comfort me, my couch shall ease my complaint.”
Then you frighten me with dreams, and terrify me through visions.
So that my soul chooses strangling, death rather than my bones.
I loathe my life; I would not live forever. Leave me alone, for my days are but a breath.
What is man, that you should magnify him, and that you should set your heart upon him?
And that you visit him every morning, and test him every moment.
How long will You not look away from me, nor let me alone till I swallow my spittle?
I have sinned; what shall I do to You, watcher of man? Why have You set me as a target for You, so that I have become a burden to myself?
And why do You not bear my transgression and cause my iniquity to pass away? For now I shall lie down in the dust, and You will seek me diligently, but I shall not be.
Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,
How long will you speak these things, and the words of your mouth be a mighty wind?
Does God pervert justice, or does the Almighty pervert righteousness?
If your children have sinned against Him, He has delivered them into the hand of their transgression.
If you will earnestly seek to God, and make your supplication to the Almighty,
If you are pure and upright, surely now He will rouse Himself for you and restore the habitation of your righteousness.
And though your beginning was small, yet your latter end will increase exceedingly.
For inquire, I pray you, of the former generation, and set your mind to the search of their fathers.
For we are but of yesterday, and know nothing, for our days upon earth are a shadow.
Will they not instruct you and speak to you, and from their heart bring forth words?
Can the papyrus grow tall without a marsh? Can the reed flourish without water?
While it is still in its greenness and not cut down, it withers before any other grass.
So are the paths of all who forget God, and the hope of the godless shall perish.
Whose confidence shall be cut off, and whose trust is a spider’s house.
He leans upon his house, but it shall not stand; he holds fast to it, but it shall not endure.
He is moist before the sun, and over his garden his shoots spread forth.
His roots are wrapped about the stone-heap; he looks upon a house of stones.
If he is swallowed up from his place, then it will deny him, saying, I have not seen you.
Behold, this is the joy of his way, and out of the dust others shall spring up.
Behold, God will not reject the blameless, nor will He uphold the hand of evildoers.
Till he fill your mouth with laughter, and your lips with shouts of joy.
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame, and the tent of the wicked shall be no more.
And Job answered and said:
Truly I know that it is so; but how can a mortal be justified with God?
If one should desire to contend with Him, he could not answer Him one time out of a thousand.
Wise in heart and mighty in strength; who has hardened himself against Him and prospered?
He removes the mountains, and they know it not, when he overturns them in his anger.
He shakes the earth out of its place, and its pillars tremble.
He speaks to the sun, and it does not shine, and seals up the stars.
He alone stretches out the heavens and treads upon the heights of the sea.
Who makes the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
He does great things beyond searching out, and wonders without number.
Behold, he passes by me, and I do not see him; he moves on, and I do not perceive him.
Behold, he snatches away; who can turn him back? Who will say to him, What are you doing?
God does not turn back His anger; beneath Him bow down the helpers of Rahab.
How much less shall I answer Him, and choose out my words to reason with Him?
Though I were in the right, I would not answer; I would plead for grace to my Judge.
If I had called and he answered me, I would not believe that he had listened to my voice.
He who crushes me with a tempest and multiplies my wounds without cause.
He will not allow me to catch my breath, but fills me with bitterness.
If it is a matter of strength, behold, He is mighty; and if of justice, who will summon me?
Though I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me; though I were blameless, it would prove me perverse.
I am blameless; I do not know myself; I despise my life.
It is all one; therefore I said, He destroys the blameless and the wicked.
If the scourge slays suddenly, He mocks at the trial of the innocent.
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; he covers the faces of its judges. If it is not he, then who is it?
My days are swifter than a runner; they flee away, they see no good.
They have passed by like swift ships, like an eagle swooping upon the prey.
If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my sad countenance and be of good cheer.
I am afraid of all my sorrows; I know that you will not hold me innocent.
I shall be condemned; why then do I labor in vain?
If I wash myself with snow water, and cleanse my hands with lye,
Yet You will plunge me into the pit, and my own garments will abhor me.
For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, that we should come together in judgment.
There is no arbiter between us, who might lay his hand upon us both.
Let Him take His rod away from me, and let His terror not overwhelm me.
I would speak and not fear Him, for I am not so with myself.
My soul is weary of my life; I will give free course to my complaint; I will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I will say to God, Do not condemn me; make me know why You contend with me.
Is it good for you that you should oppress, that you should despise the toil of your hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
Do you have eyes of flesh, or do you see as a mortal man sees?
Are your days as the days of mortal man, or your years as the days of a strong man?
That you should seek out my iniquity and search after my sin.
Although you know that I am not wicked, and there is none who can deliver out of your hand.
Your hands have shaped me and made me, together all around; yet you swallow me up.
Remember, I pray, that as clay you have fashioned me, and to dust you will return me.
Did you not pour me out like milk, and curdle me like cheese?
With skin and flesh you clothed me, and with bones and sinews you knit me together.
Life and lovingkindness you have granted me, and your care has preserved my spirit.
Yet these things you have hidden in your heart; I know that this was with you.
If I sin, then you watch me, and from my iniquity you will not acquit me.
If I am wicked, woe to me; and if I am righteous, I dare not lift up my head, being filled with disgrace and seeing my affliction.
And if my head is lifted up, like a lion you hunt me, and again you show yourself marvelous against me.
You renew your witnesses against me and increase your anger with me; changes and a host are with me.
Why then did You bring me forth from the womb? I should have expired, and no eye would have seen me.
I should have been as though I had not been; carried from the womb to the grave.
Are not my days few? Cease then, and let me alone, that I may take a little comfort.
Before I go—and shall not return—to the land of darkness and of the shadow of death.
A land of gloom like thick darkness, of the shadow of death without any order, where the light is as darkness.
Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
Should a multitude of words go unanswered, and shall a man of lips be justified?
Shall your empty words make men hold their peace, and will you mock and none put you to shame?
For you have said, “My doctrine is pure, and I have been clean in your eyes.”
But oh that God would speak, and open His lips against you.
And that he would declare to you the hidden things of wisdom, for they are double to sound understanding. Know then that God exacts of you less than your iniquity deserves.
Can you find out the deep things of God? Can you attain to the limit of the Almighty?
It is higher than heaven—what can you do? Deeper than Sheol—what can you know?
It is longer than the earth in measure, and broader than the sea.
If he passes through, and shuts up, and summons an assembly, then who can turn him back?
For he himself knows men of vanity; and he sees iniquity, and will he not consider it?
But an empty man will gain a heart, and the colt of a wild donkey will be born a man.
If you set your heart aright and spread out your hands to Him,
If iniquity is in your hand, put it far away, and let not unrighteousness dwell in your tents.
For then you will lift up your face without blemish; you will be steadfast and will not fear.
For you shall forget misery; you shall remember it as waters that have passed away.
And life shall arise brighter than noonday; though there be darkness, it shall be as the morning.
And you shall trust, because there is hope; and you shall look about you in safety, and you shall lie down.
And you shall lie down, and none shall make you afraid; and many shall entreat your favor.
But the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and escape shall vanish from them, and their hope shall be the breathing out of the soul.
And Job answered and said.
Truly then, you are the people, and with you wisdom will die.
I also have a heart as well as you; I do not fall short of you. And who does not know things such as these?
I am a laughingstock to my friend, I who called upon God and He answered him; a laughingstock is the righteous, the blameless man.
Contempt for calamity is in the thought of one at ease; it is ready for those whose foot is slipping.
At ease are the tents of plunderers, and secure are they who provoke God, those who bring God into their hand.
But now, ask the beasts, and they will teach you; and the birds of the heavens, and they will tell you.
Or speak to the earth, and it will teach you, and the fish of the sea will declare to you.
Who does not know among all these that the hand of the LORD has done this?
In whose hand is the life of every living thing, and the breath of all mankind.
Does not the ear test words, and the palate taste its food?
With the aged is wisdom, and with length of days understanding.
With Him are wisdom and might; to Him belong counsel and understanding.
Behold, he breaks down, and it cannot be built again; he shuts a man in, and it cannot be opened.
Behold, he restrains the waters, and they dry up; and he sends them out, and they overturn the earth.
With Him are strength and sound wisdom; His are the one who errs and the one who leads astray.
He leads counselors away stripped, and makes judges go mad.
He loosens the discipline of kings, and binds a girdle upon their loins.
He leads priests away stripped, and overthrows the mighty.
He removes the speech of the trusted and takes away the understanding of the elders.
He pours contempt upon nobles, and loosens the belt of the mighty.
He uncovers deep things out of darkness, and brings the shadow of death into the light.
He makes nations great, and destroys them; he spreads out the nations, and leads them away.
He removes the heart of the chiefs of the people of the earth, and makes them wander in a trackless waste where there is no way.
They grope in darkness, and not in light, and he makes them wander like a drunkard.
Behold, my eye has seen all this; my ear has heard and understood it.
What you know, I also know; I am not inferior to you.
But I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to argue my case with God.
But indeed you are forgers of lies; all of you are physicians of no value.
Oh that you would altogether hold your peace, and it would be your wisdom.
Hear now my reproof, and give ear to the pleadings of my lips.
Will you speak unrighteousness for God, and speak deceitfully for Him?
Will you show partiality in his favor? Will you contend for God?
Will it be good when He searches you out? Or as one deceives a mortal, will you deceive Him?
He will surely reprove you if in secret you show partiality.
Will not his majesty terrify you, and his dread fall upon you?
Your remembered sayings are proverbs of ashes; your defenses are defenses of clay.
Be silent before me, and I will speak, and let come upon me what may.
Why should I take my flesh in my teeth and put my life in my hand?
Though he slay me, I will wait for him; yet I will argue my ways before his face.
He also shall be my salvation, for a hypocrite shall not come before Him.
Hear diligently my words, and let my declaration be in your ears.
Behold now, I have prepared my case; I know that I shall be justified.
Who is he that will contend with me? For then I would hold my peace and give up the ghost.
Only two things do not do to me; then from Your presence I will not hide myself.
Withdraw Your hand far from me, and let not Your terror frighten me.
Then call, and I will answer; or let me speak, and you reply to me.
How many are my iniquities and sins? Make known to me my transgression and my sin.
Why do You hide Your face and regard me as an enemy to You?
Will you frighten a driven leaf, and will you pursue the dry chaff?
For you write bitter things against me, and make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
You also put my feet in the stocks, and watch all my paths; upon the soles of my feet you set your mark.
And he, like rottenness, wastes away, like a garment that the moth has consumed.
Man that is born of woman is of few days and full of trouble.
Like a flower he comes forth and withers; he flees like a shadow and does not remain.
And upon this also You have opened Your eyes, and You bring me into judgment with You.
Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? Not one.
Since his days are determined, the number of his months is with You; You have appointed his bounds, and he shall not pass.
Turn from him, that he may rest, till he shall enjoy his day as a hired laborer.
For there is hope for a tree, that if it be cut down, it will yet sprout again, and its tender shoot will not cease.
Though its root grows old in the earth, and its stump dies in the dust.
At the scent of water it will bud, and bring forth boughs like a newly planted tree.
But a man dies and is brought low; a human expires, and where is he?
As waters run off from the sea, and a river dries up and withers.
So a man lies down and does not rise; until the heavens are no more, they will not awake, nor be roused out of their sleep.
Oh that you would hide me in Sheol, conceal me until your wrath is past, appoint for me a set time, and remember me.
If a man dies, shall he live again? All the days of my appointed service I will wait, until my renewal comes.
You will call, and I will answer You; You will long for the work of Your hands.
For now surely you number my steps; you do not watch over my sin.
My transgression is sealed up in a bag, and you fasten tight upon my iniquity.
But surely the mountain falling crumbles away, and the rock is removed from its place.
Water wears away stones; its torrents sweep away the soil of the earth; so you destroy the hope of man.
You overpower him forever, and he passes on; you change his countenance and send him away.
His sons come to honor, and he does not know it; they are brought low, but he does not perceive it of them.
Only his flesh upon him will feel pain, and his soul within him will mourn.
Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
Shall a wise man answer with knowledge of the wind, and fill his belly with the east wind?
Should he argue with a word that is of no profit, and with speeches that do not avail?
Yes, you indeed tear apart fear of God, and diminish meditation before God.
For your iniquity teaches your mouth, and you choose the tongue of the crafty.
Your own mouth condemns you, and not I; your own lips testify against you.
Were you born as the first man, and were you brought forth before the hills?
Do you listen in the council of God, and do you draw wisdom to yourself alone?
What do you know that we do not know? What do you understand that is not with us?
Both the gray-headed and the very aged are among us, men greater in days than your father.
Are the consolations of God too small for you, and the word spoken gently with you?
What has your heart carried you away, and what do your eyes wink at?
That you turn your spirit against God, and let such words go out from your mouth.
What is man, that he should be pure, and how shall one born of woman be righteous?
Behold, he puts no trust in his holy ones, and the heavens are not pure in his eyes.
How much more abominable and corrupt is man, who drinks in iniquity like water.
I will show you; listen to me, and that which I have seen I will declare.
Which wise men have declared, and did not hide, that which they received from their fathers.
To them alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them.
All the days of the wicked he is writhing in torment, and the number of years is laid up for the ruthless.
A sound of terrors is in his ears; in prosperity the destroyer shall come upon him.
He does not believe that he will return out of darkness, and he is watched for by the sword.
He wanders about for bread, saying, “Where is it?” He knows that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.
Distress and anguish terrify him; they overpower him like a king ready for the assault.
For he has stretched out his hand against God, and against the Almighty he behaves himself proudly.
He runs at Him with a stiff neck, with the thick bosses of his shields.
For he has covered his face with his fat, and made folds of flesh upon his loins.
He dwells in cities laid waste, in houses where none shall live, which are ready to become heaps.
He shall not be rich, and his wealth shall not endure, nor shall their possessions spread over the earth.
He shall not depart from darkness; the flame shall dry up his branch, and by the breath of His mouth he shall be carried away.
Let him not trust in vanity, deceiving himself, for vanity shall be his recompense.
It shall be fulfilled before his day, and his branch shall not be green.
He shall shake off his unripe grape like the vine, and shall cast off his blossom like the olive tree.
For the company of the godless is barren, and fire consumes the tents of bribery.
They conceive mischief and bring forth iniquity, and their womb prepares deceit.
And Job answered and said:
I have heard many such things; miserable comforters are you all.
Is there an end to windy words, or what provokes you that you answer?
I also could speak as you do, if your soul were in the place of my soul; I could heap up words against you, and shake my head at you.
I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the moving of my lips would restrain sorrow.
Though I speak, my pain is not restrained; and though I forbear, what departs from me?
Surely now he has worn me out; you have made desolate all my company.
You have shriveled me, which is a witness against me, and my leanness rises up against me; it testifies to my face.
His wrath has torn and persecuted me; he has gnashed upon me with his teeth; my adversary sharpens his eyes against me.
They have gaped upon me with their mouth; in reproach they strike my cheek; together they gather themselves against me.
God delivers me over to the perverse, and into the hands of the wicked he casts me down.
I was at ease, and he shattered me; he seized me by the neck and crushed me, and he set me up for himself as a target.
His archers surround me; he pierces my kidneys and does not spare; he pours out my gall upon the ground.
He breaks me with breach upon breach; he runs upon me like a mighty warrior.
I have sewn sackcloth upon my skin, and have laid my horn in the dust.
My face is reddened with weeping, and on my eyelids is deep darkness.
Although there is no violence in my hands, and my prayer is pure.
O earth, do not cover my blood, and let there be no place for my cry.
Even now, behold, my witness is in heaven, and he who testifies for me is on high.
My intercessor is my friend; before God my eye pours out tears.
O that one might plead for a man with God, as a son of man pleads for his friend.
For the years that are numbered will come, and I shall go the way from which I shall not return.
My spirit is broken, my days are extinguished, the grave is ready for me.
Surely mockers are with me, and my eye lodges upon their provocations.
Lay down now, I pray, a pledge for me with Yourself; who is he that will strike hands with me?
For you have hidden their heart from understanding; therefore you will not exalt them.
He who denounces friends for a share, the eyes of his children shall fail.
He has made me a byword among the peoples, and I am one in whose face they spit.
My eye has grown dim with grief, and all my members are like a shadow.
The upright are appalled at this, and the innocent is stirred up against the godless.
Yet the righteous holds fast to his way, and he who has clean hands increases in strength.
But as for you all, turn now and come again, yet I shall not find a wise man among you.
My days are past, my plans are broken off, the desires of my heart.
They turn night into day; the light is near, in the presence of darkness.
If I look for Sheol as my house, in the darkness I have spread my couch.
I have called to the pit, “You are my father,” to the worm, “my mother and my sister.”
And where then is my hope, and my hope, who shall behold it?
Will they go down to the bars of Sheol? Shall we descend together into the dust?
Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
How long will you set an end to words? Consider, and afterward we will speak.
Why are we counted as beasts, and regarded as unclean in your eyes?
You who tear yourself in your anger, shall the earth be forsaken for your sake, and shall the rock be removed from its place?
Surely also the light of the wicked shall be put out, and the spark of his fire shall not shine.
The light is darkened in his tent, and his lamp above him is put out.
His vigorous steps are narrowed, and his own counsel shall cast him down.
For he is cast into a net by his own feet, and he walks upon a lattice of snares.
A snare shall seize him by the heel; a trap shall lay hold on him.
A snare is hidden in the earth for him, and his trap lies upon the path.
All around terrors frighten him, and chase him at his heels.
His strength shall be famished, and calamity shall be ready at his side.
It devours the parts of his skin; the firstborn of death devours his limbs.
He is torn from the security of his tent, and they march him to the king of terrors.
Strangers shall dwell in his tent; it is no more his. Brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation.
From beneath his roots shall they be dried up, and from above his branch shall be cut off.
His remembrance perishes from the earth, and he has no name upon the face of the street.
He is driven from light into darkness, and chased out of the world.
He has neither offspring nor descendant among his people, and there is no survivor in the places of his sojourning.
Those in the west are appalled at his day, and those of the east are seized with horror.
Surely such are the dwellings of the wicked, and this is the place of him who does not know God.
Then Job answered and said:
How long will you torment my soul and crush me with words?
These ten times you have reproached me; you are not ashamed that you deal harshly with me.
And even if indeed I have erred, with me remains my error.
If indeed you magnify yourselves against me and reproach me with my disgrace,
Know then indeed that God has wronged me, and has encircled me with His net.
Behold, I cry out, “Violence!” but I am not answered; I cry for help, but there is no justice.
He has fenced up my way, and I cannot pass; and upon my paths He sets darkness.
He has stripped from me my glory, and removed the crown from my head.
He breaks me down on every side, and I am gone, and He uproots my hope like a tree.
His wrath is kindled against me, and he counts me to him as one of his adversaries.
Together my troops advance; they cast up their way against me, and encamp round about my tent.
My brothers he has put far from me, and my acquaintances are wholly estranged from me.
My close relatives have ceased, and my acquaintances have forgotten me.
Sojourners in my house and my maidservants count me as a stranger; I have become a foreigner in their eyes.
I call to my servant, and he does not answer; I plead with him with my mouth.
My breath is strange to my wife, and I am loathsome to the children of my own body.
Even young children despise me; I rise up, and they speak against me.
All the men of my council abhor me, and those I loved are turned against me.
My bone clings to my skin and to my flesh, and I have escaped with the skin of my teeth.
Have pity on me, have pity on me, O you my friends, for the hand of God has struck me.
Why do you pursue me like God, and are not satisfied with my flesh?
Oh that my words were now written! Oh that they were inscribed in a book!
That with an iron pen and lead they were engraved in the rock forever.
But as for me, I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last he will stand upon the dust.
And after my skin has been thus destroyed, yet from my flesh I shall behold God.
Whom I myself shall behold, and my eyes shall see, and not another; my innermost being is consumed within my bosom.
If you say, “How shall we persecute him, and that the root of the matter is found in me?”
Be afraid for yourselves of the sword, for wrath is among the iniquities of the sword, so that you may know there is a judgment.
Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
Therefore my troubled thoughts make me answer, and because of this my inward haste is within me.
The reproof of my reproach I hear, and the spirit of my understanding answers me.
Do you not know this from of old, since man was placed upon the earth,
For the exulting of the wicked is short, and the joy of the godless is but for a moment.
Though his height ascend to the heavens, and his head reach to the clouds,
Like his own dung he shall perish forever; those who have seen him shall say, “Where is he?”
Like a dream he shall fly away, and they shall not find him; and he shall be chased away as a vision of the night.
The eye that looked upon him shall do so no more, and his place shall behold him no longer.
His children shall seek the favor of the poor, and his hands shall restore his wealth.
His bones are full of his youthful vigor, but it shall lie down with him in the dust.
Though evil is sweet in his mouth, though he hides it under his tongue,
He spares it and does not let it go, and holds it back within his mouth.
His food is turned within his bowels; the venom of asps is within him.
He has swallowed down riches, and he shall vomit them up again; God shall cast them out of his belly.
He shall suck the poison of vipers; the tongue of the adder shall slay him.
He shall not look upon the streams, the flowing rivers of honey and cream.
That which he labored for he shall restore, and shall not swallow it down; according to the wealth of his exchange, and he shall not rejoice in it.
For he has crushed and forsaken the poor; he has seized a house, and he shall not build it up.
Because he knew no quietness within his belly, he shall not escape with that which he delights in.
Nothing is left for him to devour; therefore his prosperity shall not endure.
In the fullness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits; the hand of every toiler shall come upon him.
When he is about to fill his belly, He will send upon him the fury of His anger, and will rain it upon them for their food.
He shall flee from the iron weapon, and a bow of bronze shall pierce him through.
He draws it forth, and it comes out of his body; yes, the glittering point comes out of his gall. Terrors come upon him.
All darkness is laid up for his treasures; a fire not blown shall consume him; it shall devour what remains in his tent.
The heavens shall reveal his iniquity, and the earth shall rise up against him.
The increase of his house shall depart, flowing away in the day of his wrath.
This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the inheritance decreed for him by God.
And Job answered and said:
Hear, O hear my speech, and let this be your consolations.
Bear with me, and I also will speak; and after I have spoken, you may mock.
As for me, is my complaint directed to man? And why then should my spirit not be short?
Turn toward me and be appalled, and lay your hand upon your mouth.
Even when I remember, I am dismayed, and trembling seizes my flesh.
Why do the wicked live on, grow old, and also increase in power?
Their seed is established with them in their sight, and their offspring before their eyes.
Their houses are peace from fear, and the rod of God is not upon them.
His bull breeds and does not fail; his cow calves and does not miscarry.
They send forth their little ones like a flock, and their children dance.
They lift up the timbrel and harp, and rejoice at the sound of the pipe.
They spend their days in prosperity, and in a moment they go down to Sheol.
And they say to God, “Depart from us, for in the knowledge of Your ways we have no delight.”
Who is the Almighty, that we should serve Him? And what profit do we have if we entreat Him?
Behold, their good is not in their own hand; far be from me the counsel of the wicked.
How often is the lamp of the wicked put out, and calamity comes upon them, and sorrows does He distribute in His anger?
Let them be as chaff before the wind, and as stubble that the storm steals away.
God lays up his iniquity for his children; let him repay it to him, that he may know it.
His own eyes shall see his calamity, and from the wrath of the Almighty he shall drink.
For what is his delight in his house after him, when the number of his months is cut off?
Shall anyone teach knowledge to God, seeing that He judges those who are on high?
One dies in the fullness of his integrity, being wholly at ease and quiet.
His pails are full of milk, and the marrow of his bones is moistened.
And another dies with a bitter soul, and has not eaten of good.
Together they lie down in the dust, and the worm covers them.
Behold, I know your thoughts, and the schemes with which you wrong me.
For you say, “Where is the house of the noble, and where is the tent, the dwelling places of the wicked?”
Have you not asked those who pass along the way, and do you not recognize their signs?
For the wicked is spared for the day of calamity; they are led forth for the day of wrath.
Who will declare his way to his face, and what he has done who will repay to him?
Yet he is borne to the graves, and a watch is kept over the tomb.
Sweet to him are the clods of the valley, and after him every man draws on, and before him there is no number.
And how then do you comfort me with vanity, when your answers remain as treachery?
Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
Can a man be of profit to God, for surely he who is wise is profitable only to himself?
Is it any delight to the Almighty that you are righteous, or any gain to Him that you make your ways blameless?
Is it for your fear of him that he reproves you, that he enters into judgment with you?
Is not your wickedness great, and is there no end to your iniquities?
For you have taken pledges of your brother without cause, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
You have not given water to the weary to drink, and from the hungry you have withheld bread.
But as for the man of arm, the land was his, and the one lifted up in countenance dwelt in it.
Widows you have sent away empty, and the arms of the fatherless are crushed.
Therefore snares are all around you, and sudden terror troubles you.
Or darkness, so that you do not see, and a flood of waters covers you.
Is not God in the height of heaven? And behold the head of the stars, how high they are.
And you say, “What does God know? Can He judge through the thick darkness?”
Clouds are a covering to Him, so that He does not see, and He walks on the circuit of heaven.
Will you keep to the ancient path which wicked men have trodden?
Who were snatched away before their time; a river was poured out upon their foundation.
They said to God, “Depart from us,” and, “What can the Almighty do to us?”
Yet he filled their houses with good things; but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
The righteous see it and are glad, and the innocent laughs them to scorn.
“Surely our adversaries are cut off, and the remnant of them the fire has consumed.”
Now acquaint yourself with Him, and be at peace; in this shall your good come to you.
Receive, I pray you, instruction from his mouth, and lay up his words in your heart.
If you return to the Almighty, you shall be built up; you shall put unrighteousness far away from your tents.
And lay your treasure in the dust, and the gold of Ophir among the stones of the brooks.
And the Almighty shall be your gold, and silver of choicest treasure for you.
For then you will delight yourself in the Almighty, and you will lift up your face to God.
You will pray to Him, and He will hear you, and you will pay your vows.
You will also decree a thing, and it shall be established for you, and light will shine upon your ways.
When they are cast down, then you shall say, “Exaltation!” and he shall save the one of downcast eyes.
He shall deliver one who is not innocent; and he shall be delivered through the cleanness of your hands.
Then Job answered and said:
Even today my complaint is bitter; my hand is heavy upon my groaning.
Oh that I knew where I might find Him, that I might come even to His seat.
I would set in order my cause before him, and fill my mouth with arguments.
I would know the words with which He would answer me, and understand what He would say to me.
Would he contend with me in the greatness of his power? No; surely he himself would give heed to me.
There the upright would reason with Him, and I would be delivered forever from my judge.
Behold, I go forward, but he is not there; and backward, but I cannot perceive him.
On the left hand, when He is working, I cannot grasp Him; He turns to the right hand, but I do not see Him.
For He knows the way that is with me; when He has tried me, I shall come forth as gold.
My foot has held fast to his steps; his way I have kept, and not turned aside.
The commandment of his lips I have not departed from; I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my appointed portion.
But he is of one mind, and who can turn him back? What his soul desires, that he performs.
For he will complete what is decreed for me, and like these there are many such things with him.
Therefore I am terrified before him; I consider, and I am afraid of him.
And God has made my heart faint, and the Almighty has terrified me.
For I was not cut off before the darkness, and from my face deep gloom covered.
Why are times not laid up by the Almighty, and why do those who know Him not see His days?
They remove the landmarks; they seize flocks and pasture them.
They drive away the donkey of the fatherless; they take in pledge the widow’s ox.
They turn the needy out of the way; together the poor of the land must hide.
Behold, like wild donkeys in the wilderness they go out to their work, seeking earnestly for prey; the desert is for him bread for the children.
In the field they reap his fodder, and the vineyard of the wicked they glean.
Naked they lodge without clothing, and have no covering in the cold.
They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and for lack of shelter they embrace the rock.
They snatch the fatherless from the breast, and against the poor they take a pledge.
Naked they go about without clothing, and hungry they carry the sheaves.
Between their rows they press out oil; they tread the winepresses, yet they thirst.
From out of the city men groan, and the soul of the slain cries out, yet God does not lay folly to their charge.
They are of those who rebel against the light; they know not its ways, nor abide in its paths.
At the light the murderer rises; he kills the poor and needy, and in the night he is like a thief.
The eye of the adulterer also watches for the twilight, saying, “No eye shall see me,” and he puts a covering on his face.
In the dark they dig through houses; by day they shut themselves in; they know not the light.
For together the morning is to them as the shadow of death, for they are well acquainted with the terrors of the shadow of death.
Swift is he upon the face of the waters; cursed is their portion in the earth; he does not turn toward the way of vineyards.
Drought and heat snatch away the waters of snow; so Sheol takes those who have sinned.
The womb forgets him; the worm feeds sweetly on him; he shall be remembered no more, and wickedness is broken like a tree.
He preys upon the barren woman who does not bear, and to the widow he does no good.
Yet God draws away the mighty by His power; he rises up, though he does not trust his own life.
He grants him to be secure, and he leans upon it, yet His eyes are upon their ways.
They are exalted for a little while, and they are no more; they are brought low, like all others they are gathered in, and like the top of the ear of grain they wither.
And if it be not so, who will prove me a liar, and make my word of no account?
Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
Dominion and fear are with Him; He makes peace in His high places.
Is there any number to his armies? And upon whom does his light not arise?
How then can man be righteous with God, and how can one born of woman be pure?
Behold, even the moon has no brightness, and the stars are not pure in my eyes.
How much less man, who is a maggot, and the son of man, who is a worm.
Then Job answered and said:
How you have helped one without strength, and saved the arm that has no might.
How you have counseled one without wisdom, and abundantly made sound knowledge known!
For whom have you uttered words, and whose spirit has gone out from you?
The shades tremble beneath the waters and their inhabitants.
Sheol is naked before Him, and Abaddon has no covering.
He stretches out the north over the void, and hangs the earth upon nothing.
He binds up the waters in his thick clouds, and the cloud is not torn under them.
He holds fast the face of the throne; He spreads His cloud upon it.
He has inscribed a boundary upon the face of the waters, to the limit of light with darkness.
The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished at his rebuke.
By His power He stilled the sea, and by His understanding He shattered Rahab.
By His breath the heavens are made fair; His hand has pierced the fleeing serpent.
Behold, these are but the fringes of His ways, and what a whisper of a word is heard of Him; but the thunder of His mighty deeds, who can understand?
And Job again took up his parable and said:
As God lives, who has taken away my justice, and the Almighty, who has made my soul bitter,
For as long as my breath is in me, and the spirit of God is in my nostrils.
My lips shall not speak injustice, nor shall my tongue utter deceit.
Far be it from me to declare you in the right; till I die I will not remove my integrity from me.
In my righteousness I hold fast and will not let it go; my heart shall not reproach me for any of my days.
Let my enemy be as the wicked, and he that rises up against me as the unrighteous.
For what is the hope of the godless, when he is cut off, when God takes away his soul?
Will God hear his cry when distress comes upon him?
Will he delight himself in the Almighty? Will he call upon God at all times?
I will teach you concerning the hand of God; what is with the Almighty I will not conceal.
Behold, all of you yourselves have seen it; and why then do you vainly indulge in vanity?
This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the inheritance of the ruthless, which they receive from the Almighty.
If his children are multiplied, it is for the sword, and his offspring shall not be satisfied with bread.
Those who survive him shall be buried by the plague, and his widows shall not weep.
Though he heap up silver like dust, and prepare garments as the clay,
He may prepare it, but the righteous shall wear it, and the innocent shall divide the silver.
He builds his house like a moth, and like a booth that a watchman makes.
The rich man lies down, but he is not gathered; he opens his eyes, and he is no more.
Terrors overtake him like waters; in the night a storm-wind steals him away.
An east wind lifts him up, and he is gone; it sweeps him out of his place.
And it hurls itself upon him and does not spare; from His hand he will surely flee.
It claps its hands over him, and hisses at him from its place.
Surely there is a mine for silver, and a place where they refine gold.
Iron is taken out of the dust, and copper is smelted from the stone.
He sets an end to darkness, and to every extremity he searches out, the stone of deepest gloom and of the shadow of death.
A torrent breaks forth away from where people sojourn; forgotten by the foot, they hang suspended far from men, they swing to and fro.
The earth, from it comes forth bread, but underneath it is turned up as by fire.
Its stones are the place of sapphires, and it has dust of gold.
A path that no bird of prey knows, and the falcon’s eye has not seen.
The proud beasts have not trodden it, nor has the fierce lion passed over it.
He stretches out his hand against the flinty rock; he overturns the mountains at the root.
He cuts out channels through the rocks, and his eye beholds every precious thing.
He dams up the streams from weeping, and the hidden thing he brings forth to the light.
But where shall wisdom be found? And where is the place of understanding?
Man does not know its worth, and it is not found in the land of the living.
The deep says, “It is not in me,” and the sea says, “It is not with me.”
It cannot be gotten for gold, nor shall silver be weighed as its price.
It cannot be weighed with the fine gold of Ophir, with precious onyx or sapphire.
Gold and glass cannot be compared with it, nor can it be exchanged for a vessel of fine gold.
Coral and crystal shall not be remembered, and the price of wisdom is above pearls.
The topaz of Cush cannot be compared with it; with pure gold it shall not be valued.
But from where then does wisdom come, and where is the place of understanding?
And it is hidden from the eyes of every living thing, and concealed from the birds of the heavens.
Abaddon and Death say, “With our ears we have heard a report of it.”
God understands its way, and He knows its place.
For he looks to the ends of the earth, and sees under all the heavens.
To make the wind its weight, and to measure out the waters by measure.
When He made a decree for the rain, and a path for the thunderbolts of His voice.
Then He saw it and declared it; He established it, and also searched it out.
And He said to man, “Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.”
And Job again took up his parable and said:
Oh that I were as in months of old, as in the days when God watched over me.
When His lamp shone upon my head, by His light I walked through darkness.
as I was in the days of my prime, when the counsel of God rested upon my tent
When the Almighty was yet with me, and my children were round about me.
When my steps were washed with cream, and the rock poured out for me streams of oil.
When I went out to the gate by the city, I prepared my seat in the square.
The young men saw me and hid themselves, and the aged arose and stood.
Princes refrained from words, and laid their hand upon their mouth.
The voice of nobles was hushed, and their tongue clung to the roof of their mouth.
For the ear heard and blessed me, and the eye saw and bore witness of me.
For I delivered the poor who cried for help, and the orphan who had no helper.
The blessing of him who was perishing came upon me, and I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy.
I put on righteousness, and it clothed me; my justice was as a robe and a turban.
I was eyes to the blind, and feet was I to the lame.
I was a father to the needy, and the cause I did not know I searched out.
And I broke the fangs of the wicked, and from his teeth I cast out the prey.
Then I said, “I shall die in my nest, and I shall multiply my days like the sand.”
My root is spread out to the waters, and the dew lodges all night upon my harvest.
My glory is fresh with me, and my bow is renewed in my hand.
to me they listened and waited, and kept silence for my counsel.
After my word they spoke no more, and my speech dropped upon them like gentle rain.
They waited for me as for the rain, and they opened their mouth wide as for the latter rain.
I smiled on them, and they did not believe it; and the light of my countenance they did not cast down.
I chose their way and sat as chief, and dwelt as a king in the army, as one who comforts the mourners.
But now those younger than I laugh me to scorn, whose fathers I would have disdained to set with the dogs of my flock.
Yea, the strength of their hands, of what use was it to me? In them vigor was perished.
Gaunt with want and famine, they are wasted to a skeleton, fleeing to the parched wilderness of yesternight’s desolation and ruin.
Who pluck saltwort by the bushes, and whose food is the roots of the broom.
They were driven forth from the midst; they shouted against them as against a thief.
In the ravines of the valleys they must dwell, in holes of the dust and of the rocks.
Among the bushes they bray; beneath the nettles they huddle together.
Sons of the foolish, yes, sons of the nameless, they were scourged out of the land.
And now I have become their song, and I am a byword to them.
They abhor me, they stand far from me; and from my face they do not withhold their spit.
Because He has loosed His cord and afflicted me, they also have cast off the bridle before my face.
On my right hand a brood of rabble rise up; they thrust aside my feet, and cast up against me the paths of their ruin.
They tear up my path, they further my calamity; there is none to help them.
As through a wide breach they come on; beneath the crash they roll themselves along.
Terrors are turned upon me; my honor is pursued as by the wind, and my salvation has passed away like a cloud.
And now my soul is poured out within me; the days of affliction have taken hold of me.
By night my bones are pierced within me, and my sinews find no rest.
By great force my garment is disfigured; it binds me about like the collar of my tunic.
He has cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust and ashes.
I cry to You, but You do not answer me; I stand, and You gaze intently upon me.
You have turned cruel to me; with the might of your hand you oppose me.
You lift me up to the wind; you make me ride upon it, and you melt me in the roar of the storm.
For I know that you will bring me to death, and to the house appointed for all the living.
Surely one does not stretch out the hand to a ruin, if in his calamity there is a cry for them for help.
Did I not weep for him whose day was hard? Was not my soul grieved for the needy?
For I looked for good, and evil came; and I waited for light, but darkness came.
My inward parts are in turmoil and are never still; days of affliction confront me.
I go about in mourning, without the sun; I stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
I have become a brother to jackals, and a companion to the daughters of the owl.
My skin turns black upon me, and my bones are burned with scorching heat.
My harp is turned to mourning, and my pipe to the voice of those who weep.
I have made a covenant with my eyes; how then could I gaze upon a virgin?
And what is the portion of God from above, and the heritage of the Almighty from on high?
Is not calamity for the wicked, and disaster for the workers of iniquity?
Does He not see my ways and count all my steps?
If I have walked with falsehood, and my foot has hastened to deceit,
Let Him weigh me in righteous scales, and let God know my integrity.
If my step has turned aside from the way, and my heart has gone after my eyes, and any stain has clung to my hands,
Then let me sow, and another eat, and let my offspring be rooted out.
If my heart has been enticed toward a woman, or I have lain in wait at my neighbor’s door,
may my wife grind for another, and over her let others bow down
For this is a shameful deed, and it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
For it is a fire that consumes to destruction, and it would root out all my increase.
If I have despised the cause of my servant or my maidservant, when they contended with me;
What then shall I do when God rises up? And when He visits in judgment, what shall I answer Him?
Did not He who made me in the womb make him, and did not One fashion us together in the belly?
If I have withheld the desire of the poor, or caused the eyes of the widow to fail.
Or have I eaten my morsel alone, and the fatherless has not eaten of it?
for from my youth he grew up with me as a father, and from my mother’s womb I guided her.
If I have seen any perishing for lack of clothing, or the needy without covering,
If his loins have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my lambs.
If I have shaken my hand against the fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate.
Let my shoulder fall from its shoulder-blade, and my arm be broken from the bone.
For calamity from God was a terror to me, and because of His majesty I could not endure.
If I have made gold my confidence, and to fine gold have said, You are my trust;
If I rejoiced because my wealth was great, and because my hand had found much.
If I beheld the light when it shone, or the moon walking in splendor,
and my heart was secretly enticed, and my hand kissed my mouth
This also would be an iniquity to be judged, for I would have denied God who is above.
If I rejoiced at the ruin of him who hated me, or exulted when evil found him.
And I did not allow my mouth to sin by asking for his life with a curse.
If the men of my tent have not said, “Oh, that we might be satisfied with his flesh; we are never filled.”
The sojourner did not lodge in the street; I opened my doors to the traveler.
If I have covered my transgressions like Adam, to hide my iniquity in my bosom.
Because I feared the great multitude, and the contempt of families terrified me, so that I kept silent and did not go out of the door.
Oh that I had one to hear me! Behold, here is my mark; let the Almighty answer me, and let my adversary write out his indictment.
Surely I would bear it upon my shoulder; I would bind it to me as crowns.
The number of my steps I would declare to him; like a prince I would approach him.
If my land cries out against me, and its furrows together weep,
If I have eaten its yield without silver, or have caused the soul of its owners to breathe out,
Instead of wheat let thorns come forth, and instead of barley, noxious weeds. The words of Job are ended.
So these three men ceased from answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
Then the anger of Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, burned against Job; his wrath burned because he justified himself rather than God.
Also against his three friends his anger burned, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
Now Elihu had waited for Job with words, because they were older than he in days.
And Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of the three men, and his anger was kindled.
And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said, I am young in days, and you are aged; therefore I held back and was afraid to declare my knowledge to you.
I said, Days should speak, and the multitude of years should make wisdom known.
Surely it is the spirit in man, and the breath of the Almighty that gives them understanding.
It is not the many who are wise, nor do the aged understand justice.
Therefore I said, Listen to me; I also will declare my knowledge.
Behold, I waited for your words; I listened for your insights, until you searched out what to say.
And to you I gave heed and considered, but behold, there is none that convicts Job, none of you that answers his words.
Lest you say, “We have found wisdom; God will vanquish him, not man.”
He has not arranged words against me, and with your sayings I will not answer him.
They are dismayed, they answer no more; words have departed from them.
And I had waited, for they spoke not; for they stood still and answered no more.
I also will answer my part, I also will declare my knowledge.
For I am full of words; the spirit within me presses upon me.
Behold, my belly is like wine that has no vent; like new wineskins it is ready to burst.
I will speak, that I may find relief; I will open my lips and answer.
I pray, let me not show partiality to any man, nor flatter any human being.
For I do not know how to flatter; in a little while my Maker would take me away.
But now, Job, please hear my speech, and give ear to all my words.
Behold now, I have opened my mouth; my tongue has spoken in my palate.
The uprightness of my heart shall speak, and the knowledge of my lips shall utter what is pure.
The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
If you are able, answer me; set your words in order before me, stand forth.
Behold, I am toward God as you are; from clay I too was formed.
Behold, my terror shall not alarm you, and my pressure upon you shall not be heavy.
Surely you have spoken in my hearing, and the sound of your words I have heard.
I am pure, without transgression; I am clean, and there is no iniquity in me.
Surely he finds occasions against me; he counts me as his enemy.
He puts my feet in the stocks; He watches over all my paths.
Behold, in this you are not right; I will answer you, for God is greater than man.
Why do you contend against Him? For He does not answer all His words.
For God speaks once, and twice, yet man does not perceive it.
In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falls upon men, in slumberings upon the bed.
Then He opens the ear of men and seals their instruction.
To turn man aside from his deed, and to cover pride from a man.
He keeps his soul back from the pit, and his life from passing over to the sword.
He is also chastened with pain upon his bed, and with unceasing strife in his bones.
So that his life loathes bread, and his soul rejects the food he craves.
His flesh wastes away from sight, and his bones, once unseen, now stand out.
His soul draws near to the pit, and his life to those who bring death.
If there is for him an angel, a mediator, one out of a thousand, to declare to man what is right for him,
and He is gracious to him and says, “Deliver him from going down to the pit; I have found a ransom.”
His flesh shall be fresher than in youth; he shall return to the days of his youthful vigor.
He shall entreat God, and He will be favorable to him, and he shall behold His face with shouts of joy, and He restores to man his righteousness.
He sings before men and says, “I have sinned and made crooked what was right, yet it was not requited to me.”
He has redeemed his soul from passing into the pit, and his life shall see the light.
Behold, all these things God works, twice, three times with a man.
to bring back his soul from the pit, that he may be enlightened with the light of life.
Give ear, Job, listen to me; be silent, and I will speak.
If you have words, answer me; speak, for I desire to justify you.
If not, then listen to me; be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.
Then Elihu answered and said.
Hear my words, O wise men, and give ear to me, you who have understanding.
For the ear tests words, as the palate tastes food.
Let us choose for ourselves what is right; let us know among ourselves what is good.
For Job has said, I am righteous, but God has taken away my judgment.
Concerning my right I am counted a liar; my wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.
What man is like Job, who drinks up scoffing like water?
And he walks in company with workers of iniquity, and goes along with men of wickedness.
For he has said, “A man gains no profit when he delights himself with God.”
Therefore, men of understanding, hear me: far be it from God to do wickedness, and from the Almighty to do wrong.
For the work of a man He will repay him, and according to a man’s way He will cause it to befall him.
Surely, indeed, God will not act wickedly, and the Almighty will not pervert justice.
Who has charged Him with the earth, and who has set the whole world in order?
If he should set his heart upon himself, if he should gather to himself his spirit and his breath,
All flesh would perish together, and man would return to dust.
But if you have understanding, hear this; give ear to the voice of my words.
Shall even one who hates justice govern? And will you condemn the righteous, the Mighty One?
Is it fitting to say to a king, Worthless one, and to nobles, Wicked one?
Who shows no favor to princes, nor regards the rich more than the poor, for they all are the work of His hands.
In a moment they die, and at midnight the people are shaken and pass away, and the mighty are taken away, though not by hand.
For his eyes are upon the ways of a man, and he sees all his steps.
There is no darkness and no shadow of death where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
For He does not lay upon a man any further charge, that he should go before God in judgment.
He shatters the mighty without inquiry, and sets others in their place.
Therefore he acknowledges their deeds, and overturns them in the night, and they are crushed.
He strikes them as wicked men in the open sight of onlookers.
For that reason they turned aside from following Him, and all His ways they did not consider.
So that the cry of the poor should come to Him, and the cry of the afflicted He would hear.
When He gives quietness, who then can condemn? And when He hides His face, who then can behold Him, whether it be done to a nation or to a man alike?
So that a godless man may not reign, that he not be snares to the people.
For he has said to God, “I have borne chastisement; I will not offend again.”
Apart from what I see, you teach me; if I have wrought iniquity, I will do so no more.
Shall He recompense it from you, because you refuse? For you must choose, and not I; therefore speak what you know.
Men of understanding will say to me, and a wise man who hears me will say,
Job speaks without knowledge, and his words are without understanding.
My Father, let Job be tried to the end, for his answers among men of iniquity.
For he adds rebellion to his sin; among us he claps his hands, and multiplies his words against God.
And Elihu answered and said:
Is this what you reckon to be justice, when you say, “My righteousness is more than God’s”?
For you say, “What advantage will it be to you? What profit shall I have more than from my sin?”
I will answer you with words, and your companions with you.
Look to the heavens and see, and behold the skies, how they are higher than you.
If you have sinned, what do you accomplish against Him? And if your transgressions are many, what do you do to Him?
If you are righteous, what do you give him, or what does he receive from your hand?
Your wickedness concerns a man like yourself, and your righteousness a son of man.
Because of the multitude of oppressions they cry out; they call for help because of the arm of the mighty.
But none says, “Where is God my Maker, who gives songs in the night?”
Who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth, and makes us wiser than the birds of the heavens.
There they cry, but He does not answer, because of the pride of evil men.
Surely God will not hear vanity, and the Almighty will not regard it.
Surely though you say, “You do not behold him,” yet judgment is before him; therefore wait for him.
But now, because His anger has not yet visited, and He does not take full note of transgression.
But Job opens his mouth in vanity; without knowledge he multiplies words.
And Elihu continued and said.
Bear with me a little, and I will show you, for there are yet words on God’s behalf.
I will fetch my knowledge from afar, and to my Maker I will ascribe righteousness.
For truly my words are not false; one perfect in knowledge is with you.
Behold, God is mighty, and does not despise; mighty in strength of heart.
He does not keep the wicked alive, but grants justice to the afflicted.
He does not withdraw His eyes from the righteous, but with kings on the throne He seats them forever, and they are exalted.
And if they are bound in chains, caught in cords of affliction,
Then he declares to them their work, and their transgressions, that they have magnified themselves.
And he opens their ear to instruction, and commands that they return from iniquity.
If they hear and serve Him, they shall finish their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasantness.
But if they do not listen, they shall pass away by the sword, and shall expire without knowledge.
But the godless in heart lay up wrath; they do not cry for help when He binds them.
Their soul dies in youth, and their life among the unclean.
He delivers the afflicted by his affliction, and opens their ear in oppression.
Indeed, he has also lured you from the mouth of distress into a broad place where there is no constraint beneath it, and the comfort of your table is full of fatness.
But you are filled with the judgment of the wicked; judgment and justice take hold of you.
For wrath, lest it entice you to scoffing, and let not the greatness of the ransom turn you aside.
Will your cry avail, that it should set you in order, and not distress, and all the exertions of strength?
Do not long for the night, when peoples are taken away from their place.
Beware, do not turn to iniquity, for because of this you have chosen rather than affliction.
Behold, God is exalted in His power; who is a teacher like Him?
Who has appointed to Him His way, and who has said, You have worked iniquity?
Remember that you magnify His work, which men have sung.
All mankind has looked upon it; man beholds it from afar.
Behold, God is exalted, and we do not know Him; the number of His years is unsearchable.
For he draws up the drops of water; they distill as rain for his mist.
Which the skies pour down; they distill abundantly upon man.
Indeed, can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds, the thunderings of His pavilion?
Behold, He spreads His light upon it, and the roots of the sea He covers.
For by these he judges peoples; he gives food in abundance.
He covers His hands with the lightning, and commands it against the assailant.
His thunder declares concerning Him; the cattle also, as to what is coming up.
Indeed, at this also my heart trembles and leaps out of its place.
Hear, O hear, the tumult of His voice, and the murmur that goes forth from His mouth.
Under the whole heaven He lets it loose, and His lightning to the ends of the earth.
After it a voice roars; he thunders with the voice of his majesty, and he does not restrain them when his voice is heard.
God thunders wondrously with His voice; He does great things which we do not know.
For to the snow he says, “Be on the earth,” and to the rain shower, and to the downpour of his mighty rains.
He seals up the hand of every man, that all men of His work may know.
And the beast goes into its lair, and in their dens they abide.
Out of the chamber comes the storm, and from the scattering winds the cold.
By the breath of God ice is given, and the broad waters are held fast as in a solid mass.
Also with moisture he burdens the thick cloud; he scatters the cloud of his light.
And it is turned around by His guidances, that they may perform all that He commands them upon the face of the world, the earth.
Whether for a rod, or for his land, or for mercy, he causes it to come.
Hear this, Job; stand still and consider the wondrous works of God.
Do you know how God lays His command upon them, and causes the light of His cloud to shine forth?
Do you know the balancings of the clouds, the wondrous works of Him who is perfect in knowledge?
How your garments grow warm when He quiets the earth by the south wind.
Can you, with Him, spread out the skies, strong as a cast metal mirror?
Teach us what we shall say to Him; we cannot order our speech because of darkness.
Shall it be told Him that I would speak? Or would a man say that he is swallowed up?
And now men do not see the light, it is bright in the skies; but the wind passes over and clears them.
Out of the north comes golden splendor; upon God is awesome majesty.
The Almighty, whom we cannot find out, is great in power; and in justice and abundant righteousness, He does not oppress.
