Therefore men fear Him; He does not regard any who are wise in heart.
Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?
Gird up now your loins like a man; for I will question you, and you shall make it known to Me.
Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth? Declare, if you have understanding.
Who set its measurements, if you know, or who stretched the line upon it?
Upon what were its foundations sunk, or who laid its cornerstone?
when the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy
And who shut in the sea with doors, when it burst forth, coming out from the womb?
when I made the cloud its garment, and thick darkness its swaddling band
And I broke upon it My decree, and set bars and doors,
and I said, “Until here you shall come, and no farther; and here shall your proud waves be stayed.”
Have you, since your days began, commanded the morning, and made the dawn to know its place?
That it might take hold of the skirts of the earth, and that the wicked might be shaken out of it.
It is changed like clay under the seal, and they stand forth like a garment.
And from the wicked their light is withheld, and the high arm shall be broken.
Have you entered into the springs of the sea, or walked in the recesses of the deep?
Have the gates of death been revealed to you, or have you seen the gates of deepest darkness?
Have you considered to the breadths of the earth? Declare, if you know it all.
Where is the way where light dwells? And as for darkness, where is its place?
That you should take it to its border, and that you should discern the paths to its house.
You know, for you were then born, and the number of your days is many.
Have you entered into the storehouses of the snow, or have you seen the storehouses of the hail?
Which I have reserved for the time of trouble, for the day of battle and war.
What is the way by which the light is parted, and the east wind scattered upon the earth?
Who has cleft a channel for the torrent of rain, and a way for the lightning of the thunder?
To cause it to rain on a land where no man is, on the wilderness wherein there is no human being.
To satisfy the desolate waste and ruin, and to cause the tender grass to sprout forth.
Has the rain a father, or who has begotten the drops of dew?
Out of whose womb came the ice, and who has given birth to the frost of heaven?
The waters hide themselves like stone, and the face of the deep is bound fast.
Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades, or loose the cords of Orion?
Can you bring forth the constellations in their season, or guide the Bear with her children?
Do you know the ordinances of the heavens, or do you establish their rule on the earth?
Can you lift up your voice to the cloud, that an abundance of waters may cover you?
Can you send forth lightning, that they may go, and say to you, Here we are?
Who has put wisdom in the inward parts, or who has given understanding to the mind?
Who can number the clouds in wisdom, or who can lay down the water-skins of heaven,
When the dust is poured out as into a molten mass, and the clods cling fast together.
Will you hunt the prey for the lion, and satisfy the life of the young lions?
When they crouch in their dens, and abide in the thicket for the lying in wait.
Who prepares for the raven its prey, when its young cry out to God and wander for lack of food?
Do you know the time when the wild goats of the rock give birth? Do you observe the calving of the deer?
Do you count the months that they fulfill, and do you know the time when they bring forth?
They bow themselves, they bring forth their young; they cast out their labor pains.
Their young ones grow strong, they increase in the open field; they go forth, and do not return to them.
Who has sent out the wild donkey free, or who has loosed the bonds of the swift onager?
Whose house I have made the wilderness, and the salt land his dwelling places.
He laughs at the tumult of the city; the shouts of the driver he does not hear.
He ranges the mountains for his pasture, and searches after every green thing.
Will the wild ox be willing to serve you, or will he lodge by your manger?
Can you bind the wild ox in the furrow with its rope, or will it harrow the valleys after you?
Will you trust in him because his strength is great, and will you leave your labor to him?
Will you trust him that he will return your seed, and gather into your threshing floor?
The wing of the ostrich beats joyously; is it the pinion and plumage of the stork?
For she leaves her eggs to the earth, and warms them upon the dust.
And forgets that a foot may crush them, and that the beast of the field may trample them.
She deals harshly with her young ones, as though they were not hers; her labor is in vain, yet she is without fear.
For God has made her forget wisdom, and has not apportioned to her understanding.
When she lifts herself on high, she laughs at the horse and at its rider.
Do you give the horse his might? Do you clothe his neck with thunder?
Can you make him leap like a locust? The majesty of his snorting is terror.
He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength; he goes out to meet the weapons.
He laughs at fear and is not dismayed, and he does not turn back from the sword.
The quiver rattleth upon him, the flashing spear and the javelin.
With trembling and rage he devours the ground, and he does not believe that it is the sound of the trumpet.
At the blast of the trumpet he says, “Aha!” and from afar he scents the battle, the thunder of commanders and the shouting.
Is it by your understanding that the hawk soars, spreading its wings toward the south?
Is it at your command that the eagle soars high, and that it lifts up its nest?
He dwells on the rock and lodges upon the crag of the rock and the stronghold.
From there he searches out food; his eyes behold it from afar.
Her young ones also suck up blood, and where the slain are, there is she.
And the LORD answered Job and said:
Shall a faultfinder contend with the Almighty? He who argues with God, let him answer.
And Job answered the LORD and said:
Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer You? I lay my hand upon my mouth.
Once have I spoken, and I will not answer; yea, twice, but I will add no more.
Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
Gird up now your loins like a man; I will question you, and you shall make it known to Me.
Will you indeed annul My judgment? Will you condemn Me, that you may be justified?
Or do you have an arm like God, and can you thunder with a voice like His?
Deck yourself now with majesty and exaltation, and clothe yourself with glory and splendor.
Pour out the overflowings of your anger, and look on everyone who is proud, and bring him low.
Look on every proud one and bring him low, and tread down the wicked in their place.
Hide them together in the dust; bind their faces in secret.
Then I also will acknowledge you, that your own right hand can save you.
Behold now Behemoth, which I made with you; he eats grass like an ox.
Behold now, his strength is in his loins, and his power is in the muscles of his belly.
He bends his tail like a cedar; the sinews of his thighs are knit together.
His bones are channels of bronze; his limbs are like bars of iron.
He is the first of the ways of God; only his Maker can draw near to him with His sword.
For the mountains yield food for him, and all the beasts of the field play there.
Under the lotus trees he lies down, in the covert of the reed and the marsh.
Lotus trees cover him with their shade; the willows of the brook surround him.
Behold, though a river rages, he is not dismayed; he is confident though the Jordan should surge against his mouth.
In his eyes shall one take him; with snares shall one pierce his nose.
Will you draw out Leviathan with a hook, or with a cord sink down his tongue?
Will you put a reed rope into his nose, or pierce his jaw with a hook?
Will he make many supplications to you? Will he speak soft words to you?
Will he make a covenant with you? Will you take him for a servant forever?
Will you play with him as with a bird, or will you bind him for your maidens?
Will traders bargain over him? Will they divide him among the merchants?
Will you fill his skin with harpoons, or his head with fishing spears?
Lay your hand upon him; remember the battle, you will do so no more.
Behold, his hope is deceived; is he also cast down at the very sight of him?
None is so fierce that he dares to rouse him; who then is he that can stand before Me?
Who has first given to Me, that I should repay him? Whatever is under all the heavens is Mine.
I will not keep silence concerning his limbs, or the matter of his mighty power, and the grace of his frame.
Who has uncovered the face of his garment, or who can come within his double bridle?
Who has opened the doors of his face? All around his teeth is terror.
His proud scales are his rows of shields, shut up together as with a tight seal.
One to another they draw near; and no breath can come between them.
They are joined one to another; they clasp together and cannot be parted.
His sneezings flash forth light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the dawn.
Out of his mouth go flaming torches; sparks of fire leap forth.
Out of his nostrils goes smoke, as from a boiling pot and burning reeds.
His breath kindles coals, and a flame goes forth from his mouth.
In his neck lodges strength, and before him despair dances.
The folds of his flesh are joined together; they are cast firm upon him, immovable.
His heart is cast as a stone, yes, cast as the lower millstone.
At his lifting up the mighty are afraid; because of the crashings they are beside themselves.
The sword that reaches him cannot prevail; nor spear, dart, or coat of mail.
He regards iron as straw, and bronze as rotten wood.
The son of the bow shall not make him flee; sling-stones are turned for him into stubble.
He counts the club as stubble, and he laughs at the rattling of the spear.
Under him are sharp shards of pottery; he spreads out a threshing-sledge upon the mire.
He makes the deep boil like a pot; he makes the sea like an ointment cauldron.
After him he makes the path to shine; he regards the deep as gray-haired.
On the dust of the earth there is none like him, he who is made without fear.
He beholds every high thing; he is king over all the sons of pride.
And Job answered the LORD and said:
I know that you can do all things, and that no purpose of yours can be withheld from you.
“Who is this that hides counsel without knowledge? Therefore I have declared what I did not understand, things too wondrous for me, which I did not know.”
Hear now, and I will speak; I will ask of You, and You make it known to me.
By the hearing of the ear I had heard of You, but now my eye has seen You.
Therefore I despise myself, and repent in dust and ashes.

And it came to pass, after the LORD had spoken these words to Job, that the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My anger is kindled against you and against your two friends, for you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.

And now, take for yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, and go to My servant Job, and offer up a burnt offering for yourselves; and My servant Job shall pray for you, for I will surely accept him, so that I do not deal with you according to your folly, for you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.
So Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the LORD had spoken to them; and the LORD accepted the person of Job.
And the LORD restored the fortunes of Job when he prayed for his friends, and the LORD added to all that Job had, twofold.

Then came to him all his brothers and all his sisters and all who had known him before, and they ate bread with him in his house, and they shook their heads over him and comforted him for all the evil that the LORD had brought upon him; and each one gave him a piece of silver, and each one a ring of gold.
And the LORD blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning; and he came to have fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she-asses.
And there were born to him seven sons and three daughters.
And he called the name of the first Jemimah, and the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-happuch.
And no women were found so fair as the daughters of Job in all the land, and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
And Job lived after this one hundred and forty years, and he saw his sons and his sons’ sons, four generations.
And Job died, old and full of days.
